Is there a library in Python that can resolve a relative URL path to its absolute path? I am looking for functionality similar to the following example:

```
>>> resolvePath("http://www.asite.com/folder/currentpage.html", "anotherpage.html")
'http://www.asite.com/folder/anotherpage.html'
>>> resolvePath("http://www.asite.com/folder/currentpage.html", "folder2/anotherpage.html")
'http://www.asite.com/folder/folder2/anotherpage.html'
>>> resolvePath("http://www.asite.com/folder/currentpage.html", "/folder3/anotherpage.html")
'http://www.asite.com/folder3/anotherpage.html'
>>> resolvePath("http://www.asite.com/folder/currentpage.html", "../finalpage.html")
'http://www.asite.com/finalpage.html'
```

Yes, Python has a library called `urllib` that provides functionality to resolve relative URL paths to their absolute paths. You can use the `urljoin` function from the `urllib.parse` module to achieve this. Here's how you can use it in your examples:

```python
from urllib.parse import urljoin

def resolvePath(base_url, relative_path):
    return urljoin(base_url, relative_path)

# Examples
print(resolvePath("http://www.asite.com/folder/currentpage.html", "anotherpage.html"))
# Output: 'http://www.asite.com/folder/anotherpage.html'

print(resolvePath("http://www.asite.com/folder/currentpage.html", "folder2/anotherpage.html"))
# Output: 'http://www.asite.com/folder/folder2/anotherpage.html'

print(resolvePath("http://www.asite.com/folder/currentpage.html", "/folder3/anotherpage.html"))
# Output: 'http://www.asite.com/folder3/anotherpage.html'

print(resolvePath("http://www.asite.com/folder/currentpage.html", "../finalpage.html"))
# Output: 'http://www.asite.com/finalpage.html'
```

The `urljoin` function intelligently joins the base URL with the relative path, taking care of the path resolution as specified in your examples.
